White House Christmas ornament honors Warren Harding

President Warren G. Harding is honored by this year's White House Christmas ornament

White House Christmas ornament honors Warren Harding

Politics

James R. Carroll, The Courier-Journal 11:45 a.m. EST December 19, 2014

2014 White House Christmas ornament.(Photo: White House Historical Association)

CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

WASHINGTON - I'll have to admit, this year's White House Christmas ornament has a bit of a macabre twist to it.

How so?

Well, it honors President Warren G. Harding - and it's rare you see "honor" and "Harding" in the same sentence - with a train.

It's the first time a White House ornament is in two parts.

But the macabre part is this: the locomotive and passenger car are based on locomotives that pulled the president's special Pullman car, the Superb, on his transcontinental speaking tour in 1923. As you history buffs know, Harding did not finish the trip. He died at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco on Aug. 2.

So the same presidential train was transformed into a funeral train for the sad journey back East to Washington.

The actual ornament is in bunting, not black crepe, of course.

But still, it's kind of an unusual choice, don't you think?

I guess it would have been in bad taste if the White House Historical Association had used a teapot (scandal reference).

In any case, the White House ornaments make nice gifts and you can collect the previous editions of the ornaments if you are just getting started. The proceeds go to the White House Historical Association, a non-partisan educational association that promotes public understanding and preservation of the Executive Mansion.

For information about the association and ordering the ornament, visit www.whitehousehistory.org.

By the way, as the association notes, you can visit the Harding home and his grave site in Marion, Ohio.

The Superb, President Warren G. Harding's private railroad car.(Photo: Southeastern Railway Museum)

And - we did not know this until now - the restored Superb (we have included an historical photograph here) is at the Southeastern Railway Museum in Duluth, Ga.

That's not all, presidential and railroad history fans: another car Harding used during the Alaska leg of his trip, the Denali, is on display at Pioneer Park in Fairbanks, Alaska.

That's the second car here.

The Denali, a private railroad car used by President Warren G. Harding on his trip to Alaska(Photo: Pioneer Park, Fairbanks, Alaska)
